name: Titanium.Media.Sound
doc:
@platform android 0.8 @platform blackberry 3.1.2 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8 @editurl https://github.com/appcelerator/titanium_mobile/edit/master/apidoc/Titanium/Media/Sound.yml

An object for playing basic audio resources.

@description

The Sound object loads the entire media resource in memory before playing. If you need to support streaming, use the AudioPlayer API.

You can control how the sound interacts with other system sounds by setting Titanium.Media.audioSessionMode.

Use the Titanium.Media.createSound method to create a Sound object. You can play audio in any format supported by the target platform(s), as described in the following documents:

  • Android
  • iOS
  • Blackberry

Examples

Simple Example

Simple example of playing a WAVE file from the Resources directory.

var player = Ti.Media.createSound({url:"sound.wav"});
player.play();

property.name: STATE_BUFFERING
property.doc:
Audio data is being buffered from the network.

@platform android 3.2.0
property.shortDoc: Audio data is being buffered from the network. ...

property.name: allowBackground
property.doc:
Determines whether the audio should continue playing even when its activity is paused.

@platform android 1.3.0
property.shortDoc: Determines whether the audio should continue playing even when its activity is paused. ...

property.name: apiName
property.doc:
The name of the API that this proxy corresponds to.

@description

The value of this property is the fully qualified name of the API. For example, Button returns Ti.UI.Button.

@platform android 3.2.0 @platform blackberry 3.2.0 @platform iphone 3.2.0 @platform ipad 3.2.0 @platform mobileweb 3.2.0
property.shortDoc: The name of the API that this proxy corresponds to. ...

property.name: bubbleParent
property.doc:
Indicates if the proxy will bubble an event to its parent.

@description

Some proxies (most commonly views) have a relationship to other proxies, often established by the add() method. For example, for a button added to a window, a click event on the button would bubble up to the window. Other common parents are table sections to their rows, table views to their sections, and scrollable views to their views. Set this property to false to disable the bubbling to the proxy's parent.

@platform android 3.0.0 @platform iphone 3.0.0 @platform ipad 3.0.0
property.shortDoc: Indicates if the proxy will bubble an event to its parent. ...

property.name: duration
property.doc:
Duration of the audio resource.

@description

On iOS, playback time is reported in seconds.

On Android, time is reported in milliseconds.

Android note: Starting from Titanium 3.2.0, the remote audio plays asynchronously. The duration can only be fetched after the audio is initialized (refer to STATE_INITIALIZED).

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

property.name: lifecycleContainer
property.doc:
The Window or TabGroup whose Activity lifecycle should be triggered on the proxy.

@description

If this property is set to a Window or TabGroup, then the corresponding Activity lifecycle event callbacks will also be called on the proxy. Proxies that require the activity lifecycle will need this property set to the appropriate containing Window or TabGroup.

@platform android 3.6.0
property.shortDoc: The Window or TabGroup whose Activity lifecycle should be triggered on the proxy. ...

property.name: looping
property.doc:
Determines whether the audio should loop upon completion.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8
property.shortDoc: Determines whether the audio should loop upon completion. ...

property.name: paused
property.doc:
Indicates if the audio is paused.

@description

On iOS, this property is read-write, and you can pause and resume playback by setting this property to true or false.

On Android, this property is read-only. For portability, use pause to pause audio, and play to resume.
property.shortDoc: Indicates if the audio is paused. ...

property.name: playing
property.doc: Indicates if the audio is playing.

property.name: time
property.doc:
Current playback position of the audio.

@description

Time is reported in milliseconds.

On iOS, prior to Release 3.0, playback time is reported in seconds.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8
property.shortDoc: Current playback position of the audio. ...

property.name: url
property.doc: URL identifying the audio resource.

property.name: volume
property.doc:
Volume of the audio from 0.0 (muted) to 1.0 (loudest).

@description

This setting controls the volume of the sound relative to the overall volume setting for the device.

On iOS, to adjust the volume of the device, set the volume property of Titanium.Media.appMusicPlayer and set the Titanium.Media.audioSessionMode property to either Titanium.Media.AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_AMBIENT, Titanium.Media.AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_SOLO_AMBIENT, or Titanium.Media.AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_PLAYBACK.
property.shortDoc: Volume of the audio from 0.0 (muted) to 1.0 (loudest). ...

method.name: applyProperties
method.doc:
Applies the properties to the proxy.

@description

Properties are supplied as a dictionary. Each key-value pair in the object is applied to the proxy such that myproxy[key] = value.

params.name: props
params.doc:
A dictionary of properties to apply.

@description

To restart the audio, call play.

method.doc: Starting playing the sound, or resume playing a paused sound.

method.name: release
method.doc:
Releases all internal resources.

@description

This is typically unnecessary but can be useful if you load a large audio file in app.js, and play it only once and you would like to release all resources after your final play to reduce memory.
method.shortDoc: Releases all internal resources. ...

method.name: removeEventListener
method.doc:
Removes the specified callback as an event listener for the named event.

@description

Multiple listeners can be registered for the same event, so the callback parameter is used to determine which listener to remove.

When adding a listener, you must save a reference to the callback function in order to remove the listener later:

var listener = function() { Ti.API.info("Event listener called."); }
window.addEventListener('click', listener);

To remove the listener, pass in a reference to the callback function:

window.removeEventListener('click', listener);

params.name: name
params.doc: Name of the event.

params.name: callback
params.doc: Callback function to remove. Must be the same function passed to addEventListener.

method.shortDoc: Removes the specified callback as an event listener for the named event. ...

event.name: change
event.doc:
Fired when the state of the playback changes.

@description

This event can be generated by programmatic events, such as pausing or stopping the audio, and also by external events, such as the current state of network buffering.

params.name: state
params.doc:
Current state of playback.

This API can be assigned the following constants:

  • STATE_BUFFERING
  • STATE_INITIALIZED
  • STATE_PAUSED
  • STATE_PLAYING
  • STATE_STARTING
  • STATE_STOPPED
  • STATE_STOPPING
  • STATE_WAITING_FOR_DATA
  • STATE_WAITING_FOR_QUEUE

params.name: description
params.doc: Text description of the state of playback.

(android iphone ipad) source

Source object that fired the event.

(android iphone ipad) type

Name of the event fired.

(android iphone ipad) bubbles

True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

(android iphone ipad) cancelBubble

Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

@platform android 3.2.0

event.shortDoc: Fired when the state of the playback changes. ...

event.name: complete
event.doc: Fired when the audio has finished playing.

params.doc:
(iphone ipad android) success

Indicates if the sound was played successfully. Returns true if request succeeded, false otherwise.

(iphone ipad android) error

Error message, if any returned. Will be undefined if success is true.

(iphone ipad android) code

Error code. Error code will be 0 if success is true, nonzero otherwise. If the error was generated by the operating system, that system's error value is used. Otherwise, this value will be -1.

(android iphone ipad) source

Source object that fired the event.

(android iphone ipad) type

Name of the event fired.

(android iphone ipad) bubbles

True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

(android iphone ipad) cancelBubble

Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

event.shortDoc: Fired when the audio has finished playing. ...

event.name: error
event.doc: Fired when an error occurs while playing the audio.

params.doc:
(iphone ipad android) success

Indicates a successful operation. Returns false.

(iphone ipad android) error

Error message, if any returned. May be undefined.

(iphone ipad android) code

Error code. If the error was generated by the operating system, that system's error value is used. Otherwise, this value will be -1.

params.name: message
params.doc: Error message. Use the error property instead.

(android iphone ipad) source

Source object that fired the event.

(android iphone ipad) type

Name of the event fired.

(android iphone ipad) bubbles

True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

(android iphone ipad) cancelBubble

Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

@platform android 0.8 @platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

event.shortDoc: Fired when an error occurs while playing the audio. ...

event.doc:

@description

params.doc:

(android iphone ipad) type

Name of the event fired.

(android iphone ipad) bubbles

True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

(android iphone ipad) cancelBubble

Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

@platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

event.shortDoc: Fired  when audio playback is interrupted by the device. ...

event.name: resume
event.doc: Fired when audio playback is resumed after an interruption.

params.name: interruption
params.doc: Indicates if the resume was from an interruption.

(android iphone ipad) type

Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

@platform iphone 0.8 @platform ipad 0.8

event.shortDoc: Fired when audio playback is resumed after an interruption. ...
